comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Handwritten caption looks more like "A. I. Hoe & Wife." An Arthur I. Hoe was being sued in 1914 (and again in 1916) for refusing to pay a woman he promised to marry and support. He was president of a book publishing house. His wife was Evelyn Perry Hoe (b. 1886), of Rhode Island. They married in 1910 and had at least one daughter, Caroline Phelps Hoe. Mrs. Hoe favored suffrage. The Hoes were art collectors; there's at least one Botticelli at the Cleveland Museum of Art with their name in its history. www.clevelandart.org/provenance/prov_search.asp?artist=W

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of May 26, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20B11FC345D13738... reports on a day in court. Gives his name as Arthur Ingersoll Hoe.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: According to obits.oregonlive.com/obituaries/oregon/obituary.aspx?n=la..., they had five children, the last being twins, who died a few days apart in November 2010. "Harris, Laura, March 30, 1920 to Nov. 7, 2010 Pelling, Thyrza, March 30, 1920 to Nov. 11, 2010 Born March 30, 1920, in New York City, the twins were the last of Arthur Hoe and Evelyn Perry's five children. " Lots more family history at nigelquest.blogspot.com/2010/11/twins-obituary.html

comment._content: Thanks swanq for the title correction and the interesting details.  We will add some more information when we update.
